conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, creating a dark area on a surface.
The size and position of a shadow depend on the angle and distance of the light source relative to the object.
In the image, there are four objects: an apple, a piece of cloth, a glass, and a drumstick.
Each object casts a shadow labeled A, B, C, and D, respectively.
When the light source moves upward, it generally increases the angle of incidence of the light rays on the objects.
As the light source moves higher, the shadows tend to become smaller and more directly beneath the objects.
Initially, the shadow of the apple is slightly elongated due to the light source being at a lower angle.
As the light source moves upward, the shadow of the apple will become smaller and more circular, moving closer to the base of the apple.
The shadow of the cloth is irregular due to its shape.
With the light source moving upward, the shadow of the cloth will shrink and become more compact, aligning more closely with the cloth's position.
The glass casts a faint shadow due to its transparency.
As the light source moves upward, the shadow of the glass may become even less distinct, but it will still shrink and move closer to the glass's base.
The drumstick's shadow is elongated due to the light source's angle.
Moving the light source upward will cause the shadow of the drumstick to become shorter and move closer to the drumstick.
When the light source moves upward, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) will decrease in size and move closer to the respective objects casting them.
The shadows will become more directly beneath the objects, and their shapes will become more compact.
